article: "Tell me what you were like when you were my age," I asked my mother one afternoon. She looked up, _ at my question. After a long time she answered, "I was _ like you. Then, there was only one career for girls -- being a hard-working _ . To tell the truth, it is _ for me to tell you that I _ my mother when I was growing up. I did so much for her. Besides doing lots of housework, every night I would go into my parents' bedroom, and wash their feet with warm water. Not once did my mother ever said, 'thank you'." I stared out of the window, remembering _ I grew up, always wanting to hear a word of _ from her, but getting only the rule and _ I could never live up to . I remembered the years when she _ me to get up at six every morning and cook breakfast for the family before leaving for school. Least of all, I remembered the times she'd _ me to other girls who were as old as me and found me useless. "Nothing was ever _ enough for my mother,'' continued my mother, " but now I know she did _ me, even if she never said so. I told you this just for a _ . Yes, I love all my children, but you are my first child, the first in everything to me. I have been very strict and hard on you, but I _ you in the only way I knew. I am _ proud of you."
